comments.commentBody: Imagine if Clinton had been the beneficiary of Chinese hacking of the RNC? Imagine if Hillary had not released her tax returns? Imagine if Hillary had won the electoral college but lost the popular vote? Imagine if Hillary turned over a vast business empire to Chelsea and tried to say that was adequate and without conflict of interest. Can anyone really believe that Republicans wouldn't be calling her a corrupt traitor? Republicans said "Lock Her Up" over emails that did absolutely nothing and were of no real value because, realistically, they would have been leaked by either the Republicans or Comey's FBI NY office. But if the hacking of Democrats and a few Republicans by Russians is no big deal to Republicans, why did they get so upset over an email server in Clinton's home in the first place? This is the definition of hypocrisy isn't it. Comey talking about emails again right before the election while knowing this stuff about Trump and Co. and the Russian hacking was out there but remained silent. The sad fact here is that there is a code of ethics for everyone but Republicans and Trump in particular. People may forget he is the first Presidential candidate of any party since Nixon not to release their tax return. He says he is still under audit - I say he is lying to the American people. If he had nothing to hide he could increase his credibility just by doing so. The lack of transparency is a de facto admission of guilt and the only question is, of what? Treason anyone?
Republicans wouldn't be "upset" if all those things were done by Clinton. They would be foaming at the mouth. And so would Trump's staunch supporters.

The Republican party has made it perfectly clear that they have no other objectives than power and money for themselves and their friends. They have also figured out how to win without the support of a majority of voters. They have used the system to ensure election through gerrymandering, vote suppression, propaganda dissemination, and relentless "investigation" of political opponents. Until we change the system, we will continue to be run by the kleptocrats.

Re: "People may forget he is the first Presidential candidate of any party since Nixon not to release their tax return." He's also the first President in the entire history of the United States to have no government experience whatsoever. That alone ought to have disqualified him. Unfortunately, it gets worse: He's also a professional con man with a severe personality disorder. So he may be a Russian puppet too? Big deal: we KNOW he's allowed himself to function as an extremist-modern-REPUBLICAN puppet. That's far more dangerous.

On the perhaps presumptuous belief that this piece isn’t ONLY meant for the NYT’s black readership, I’m going to gingerly stick a white toe in the water.

At the very beginning, a lot of US feared for Barack Obama’s life, as well. This is, after all, Amurka. But then came ObamaCare, and the concern shifted to Nancy Pelosi and Harry Reid. (Well, to be honest, it wasn’t TOO much concern.)

Greatest black man in American history? A case certainly can made for EITHER Martin Luther King OR Barack Obama, but how about Frederick Douglass? I mean, it’s not like the man had ANY help from a minimally sympathetic national audience, like King and Obama did. The mountain HE had to climb to be effective REALLY earns him a place on a Mt. Rushmore, v.2., before ANYONE else is considered.

Presuming to speak for the oddly absent aging, a bit overweight and diffident white guy population in this piece, almost all of us ALSO are exceedingly happy that Barack Obama made it through alive. And, in the end, while Nancy and Harry also made it through, they seem to have gotten their just deserts anyway.

I am afraid, Robert, your view is somewhat muddy.

Barack Obama will be known for five things, and five things only...

1. Obamacare rammed down the throats of Americans with the Nancy Pelosi's callous comment: "You have to pass the bill to find out what is in it". Obamacare, even without Trump and the Republicans moving to repeal is in very stormy waters financially.

2. Regime change in Libya and the concomitant rise of ISIS, reviewed by Obama as "The JV".

3. The Iranian deal over nuclear proliferation with its central flaws and its unpalatable side deals.

4. His ineffective efforts to restore the economy to some sort of meaningful growth.

5. His leaving the nation more thoroughly divided than anyone could have imagined when he took office.

It matters not how much he was liked or how dignified he was in the office, it is what he was able to do for...and to...the nation.

And History WILL show that he did far more TO this nation that was not to its benefit than anything that he did FOR it.

What Dyson, and you Desden, fail to see is that whatever Obama has meant to the black community, he was the President of the United State, a job that involved ALL Americans

And by the measures that all presidents are measured, he has done little for ALL Americans, and even less for the people of color.

TheOWL, I agree that he was indeed a president for all Americans and as such you may feel that he did not serve you  well. However, as a person of colour I think his presidency and the manner in which he conducted himself was a shining example for POC across North America and beyond.

It is necessary for institutions to change for African-Americans to have more of a chance to attain successes. Conservatives have always claimed that first we must change the hearts of the bigots, and then they will change the institutions naturally. In other words, let's not rush things.

States as we speak are drafting even more laws to suppress the minority vote. How about changing that? Health care is about to be yanked out of the lives of the poor, including minorities. How about that institution? Taxpayer support of education is shrinking. Trump wants to use stop and frisk/racial profiling and says that protestors of excessive force are terrorists. Yes, let's wait for conservatives' hearts to change as they see Black people succeed. A very old and brutal con.

Really, I think we are over complicating this. Trump looks out for Trump. First, always. If he isn't already entwined with Russia through business deals, he plans to become so after his presidency--if not before by using his children. He knows there is money to be made there, and nothing else, including our country's interests, doesn't become part of the calculus.
comments.userLocation: Red State in the Old West

comments.commentBody:
Rima:

"I never apologize for not knowing something about myself. I’m sorry, that’s just the way I am."

Richard Luettgen - The New York Times Commentariat (2017) (mildly channeling Homer J. Simpson)

"I used to have an open mind, but my brains kept falling out."

Kacey

The people clearly did not elect him because of his ways with women.

So the answer is fairly simple, if the films were actually made:

Do what Sukarno of Indonesia did when the Soviets made many erotic videos of him with every kind of Russian women.

Trump should demand a high quality, master copy of each episode and distribute them for rent or sell in his world wide hotels, for a Netflix series, and for sale in adult video stories thru out the red states.

He can triumphantly do what Sukarno did and proclaim himself father of the developing world and lover of whatever wild Russian women he could meet.

The Russians caved in and made all the copies Sukarno demanded--which were distributed free to theaters thruout Indonesia; and Sukarno was respected and reelected in a landslide. Our founding fathers were every bit as ruthless as Trump and got a lot done, along with a lot of mistakes.

Let us demand the same for our king for four years. If he does not achieve a lot and fails to ignite the rebuilding of America, let us execute him. For losing would be his death.

John F Kennedy has a much richer sexual history as president, in bed with a mafia princess, and many others, than Trump has even been rumored to have. Let Trump not have this little tempest as an excuse for not rebuilding our infrastructure, research, development, and industries.
The possible video of Trump and golden showers prostitutes, while damning, is not actually the most important thing. The vital thing to uncover is the financial information Putin has on Trump.
Probably the stupidest comments I have ever read here in the Times. I am surprised they published it.

The Republican party needs to be careful how they handle this situation or they run the risk of being tainted by it. Between 9/11 which was caused by the inattention of the Republican president, the financial crisis also under a Republican president, the lowest approval rating in history of a non productive, largely Republican Congress for the last six years Americans are running out of patience. If anything happens because the Republican party chooses not to look into the possibility that Trump is beholden to the Russians, Democrats will be able to use it against them for a generation. This has the potential to blow up in their face and they need to take it seriously.

Country before party. We don't need another Nixon.
How about Country before Person?  After the Donald, every one else comes first.

The Republicans share with the Donald the belief that there's no such thing as bad publicity. When McConnell made his quasi-treasonous comment about the Senate's first job being to keep Obama being re-elected, he became a celebrity...which translates into votes.
Politicians have one job only - get re-elected. As evidenced by Obama's pathetic statement that he could have beaten Trump if he had been allowed to run for a third term.

Wow. It does make one wonder, with the consistent Republican failures, how they still won everything. I think the biggest mistake the HRC campaign made was not reminding the country of the Bush/Cheney failures at every opportunity, as well as the six years of the Republican Do-Nothing Congress. In their attempt to make Obama fail, they failed the country.

Agree strongly.  And look at his behavior over the past several months.  Is there anything he has said or done that indicates he sees the presidency as serving the American people?   I think he does not - he sees opportunities to further inflate his ego and bank accounts, and punish anyone who doesn't like him. How could he possibly function as president if he contradicts himself from one day to the next, displays astonishing ignorance of national and international issues, and appoints unqualified people to his Cabinet? Even with the concerns about Russia, Trump is not competent to be president.

Still wondering about FUTURE PERFECT for Utopia.  Utopia is an imagined place or state of affairs where everything is perfect.  It is not a perfect society yet to come.  In fact, I think the basic concept of utopia is its non-existence, its inability to exist in reality.  In fact, utopia derives from the Greek meaning "no place."

.
Possible argument in favor of the entry:

Like tales of moon exploration by Verne and de Bergerac, some fanciful fiction describes things that have not YET occurred. While Sir Thomas More almost definitely thought Utopia could never exist, who are we to say?

When published, "The Manchurian Candidate" probably seemed like the most fanciful of stories. I mean, come on! A national candidate who's a loudmouthed buffoon? People in high places whose first loyalty is to a foreign power? Allegations of anti-Americanism, levelled by the traitors against those who would uphold the Constitutional system? A leadership philosophy named for a candidate ("I shall fight against Iselinism with every fiber of my being")???

I think it's become clear in the 500 years since More published that there are people who think some sort of utopian society will come into being. Comedian Sarah Silverman told some of them that they were "being ridiculous" in 2016. The question mark in the clue indicates the constructor's doubts.

[If anyone else wants to jump into this, note that I don't contradict Steve L re "no place". Utopia might sound like Eutopia, meaning "good place", but More wouldn't have thought his fictional society was "good".]
Any society that could be described as a utopia must be in the future because it certainly wasn't in the past and isn't in the present.

Yes, Mr. Kristof, good points throughout. But you left out two points of crucial importance. First, the most explosive charge comes today from the British newspaper, The Independent. They claim that Christopher Steele concluded that there was a cabal within the FBI that was intentionally blocking investigation of Trump's collusion with Russia, insisting instead on investigating Hillary's emails. The Independent claims that Steele was so alarmed by this that after the election he was working for free, desperately trying to alert the other intelligence agencies to the danger. Needless to say, this is deeply disturbing, suggesting as it does institutional corruption going even beyond Trump.

Second, as for the dossier, it is not quite right to assert that there is "zero public evidence behind it." As the Guardian has pointed out, the report is written chronologically and makes a number of substantive predictions that turn out to be correct. For example, it warns about Carter Page's involvement with the Russians, an issue that became known publicly only several months later. (Note that Trump at his most recent press conference denied even knowing Page, one of his senior advisers on Russia. Why?) More importantly the dossier correctly predicted that Trump would favor giving Putin a pass on Crimea and urge a critical attitude toward NATO--all before he made any public pronouncements on these issues. This is partial verification of the report and good reason to take it seriously.

Agreed, on the partial verification already. Take a look at Malcolm Nance's views on t rump and the Russians. He looks at the circumstances like a spy would, not a journalist, since he works in the intelligence community. He said there is evidence to substantiate the claims all over the place, from personnel, to contacts, to t rump's statements timed with the Wikileaks exposures.

Excellent comment. Brings back memories of Hoover blackmailing JFK and his little brother, and MLK, with his evidence of their sexual shenanigans.
Plus ca change, plus la meme chose.

It is essential that we get this right. With the information that is public there is no informed concensus to be had. But either way, we need to know the whole story. Questions already asked need to be answered and answered clearly.
Are our intelligence agencies colluding to undermine the president elect? Has Mr. Trump been compromised and what is the entirety of his relationships with Russian entities, including the Kremlin? Are Comey's actions defensible in several matters, to include his refusal to make public this evidence earlier.
Is there a rogue element within our national security apparatus?
A full telling is due.

Trump hates ordinary people and is determined to return the country to the control of industry.   Sad.   There are a lot more ordinary people than there are industrialists, however.  Eventually this will turn out badly for Trump.  Hopefully the ordinary people of the US will not be damaged too badly.  Why does Trump hate us so much?
It is not hate, it is profit for the patrician class. The "ordinary" people as you well know did not vote for him.

And supported by Paul Ryan and Mitch. Paul Ryan, the immature, believer in fables of Hank Reardon and Dagney Talbert of Ayn Rand. The tycoon industrialists of "good".

He needs to pray more the his cherished Catholicism taught him - supposedly.
The answer is in the files in Moscow!

Dagwood:

Economic class integration is not a brutal con: it's the only real way we'll ever solve race as a problem in America. Institutions obey the dictates of those currently in power, as you so conveniently admit yourself, making my point FOR me.

Even if we give Donald Trump the benefit of the doubt, that he is not beholden in some way to Vladimir Putin, his bromance with the Russian strongman still is alarming.  It betrays a profound naivety about history and a willingness to cozy up to a ruthless dictator whose chief foreign policy goal is to undermine liberal democracies.  As Russian dissident Gary Kasparov has pointed out, it is rather odd that Trump has flip-flopped on virtually issue except for his defense of Russia and its leader.  Now, more than ever before, Trump needs to release his tax returns to help demonstrate that he has no financial ties to Russia.  He should not be able to hide behind the bogus shield of an IRS audit any longer.

Maybe it’s time for Senator Shumer to step into the breach and do something about the TransHudson Tunnels and the Northeastern rail corridor. Trump might like it just for building up his ego about building near home.

But it’s also relatively cheap as compared to a national repair everything at once. Trump might be a little appreciation in his inner circles for that. For a mere $100 billion, they could contract the entire line from Washington to Boston and a bit beyond.

That would replace the old bridges, straight lines, add new equipment. The region most important to the Trump companies would benefit directly - and no one could complain.

The funds could also be provided for the alternate high speed line from NYC to Boston right of way acquisition - and it wouldn’t hurt to correct the problem of trackage from Boston to Albany and Points West.

Wisconsin could be led to reconsider the new high speed line killed by Scott Walker and run it through Madison with regular service to Milwaukee.

But what is more likely is that Texas and Alabama and point that don’t really carry their weight will drain off too much of the “investment” to take care of Trump buddies.
What is Chuck Schumer supposed to do, in the face of solid Republican opposition to all such schemes? Wave a magic wand?

stu:

I rarely disguise my contempt for those who disagree with me. But I'm a cheap thrill -- I'm not president, VERY likely never will be, and just as unlikely to be charged with "transforming" anything (even you).

I'm trying to remember if Mr. Trump has been so unrelentingly positive about anyone else. He's said positive things about his family of course. And some of the people working in his campaign got the occasional shout-out. His cabinet appointees, random people at rallies, even President Obama have been mentioned. But no one else has gotten the continuous glowing praise that Putin has. That would be unusual coming from anyone. But Trump? The only other person he praises so highly, is himself.

I think the Russians keep pretty close tabs on any visiting Americans. Trump, a high profile businessman running a pageant, would have created some interest. It's not hard to imagine they could have lots of material on Trump. No matter what he says now, do you really think he would have been concerned there might be cameras in his rooms? And his cell phone would have been an open book. Nothing would have escaped their notice.

None of that means Trump did anything worthy of blackmail. But it's possible.
Now Trump seems to be arranging a visit with Putin. That's his priority? So much going on here, and that's one of the first things on his list.
I think there's a lot he needs to make clear to the American people. He is no longer the private businessman who can keep keep his connections private.

The most important people to Trump, in order, are 1) Trump 2) Putin (who controls the money keeping Trump's organization afloat), and 3) Ivanka (but only as a sexual object - eewwww). Democracy requires constant vigilance from its citizens. It is a thousand fold more important for each us to step up and do our best to call out and challenge the inappropriate, unConstitutional, and un-American statements and actions of our incoming goverment.

Thomas:

Come on. David is NEVER right. About anything.

It's incredibly suspicious that Trump goes out of his way to praise Putin, ignores his gangsterism, downplays his anti democratic actions in Russia, denies his illegal aggression against Ukraine, and excuses war crimes in Syria.

Trump only fans suspicion about his motives when he insists on waging an open war on US intelligence agencies. He doesn't seem to realize (or care?) that he's weakening an essential element of national security.

Unfortunately, that's exactly what you'd expect if he wanted to discredit an otherwise unimpeachable source likely to confirm his misdeeds. And Donald knows what a bad boy he's been over the years. My guess? We've heard only a small fraction of his depravities, transgressions, and dirty business dealings. And nothing yet that explains his obligations to Putin.

However, unlike rogue elements of the FBI out to get HRC without justification, disgruntled intelligence agencies here and abroad may have no choice but to find damaging information on Trump and quietly make it available to congress and the media. This is absolutely necessary if the PEOTUS threatens the safety and security of the US and its allies.

david:

Never suggested that workers have less rights than bond holders. It was Barack Obama who acted on the assumption of the reverse.

Agreed, on the partial verification already. Take a look at Malcolm Nance's views on t rump and the Russians. He looks at the circumstances like a spy would, not a journalist, since he works in the intelligence community. He said there is evidence to substantiate the claims all over the place, from personnel, to contacts, to t rump's statements timed with the Wikileaks exposures.

Donald trump saying that president Obama was born "abroad" was a LIE not an unsubstantiated rumor.  A vile, racist lie that was the foundations of his appeal.  Trump is now being accused of substantiated, though not fully verified allegations. The sex stuff is the least important - possibly embarrassing but a private matter as far as I'm concerned. It's the financial dealings that are relevant and the allegations have merit. All signs indicate trump and his people have Russian ties, do lucrative business on Russia and can easily be bought.  I count on journalists of your caliber to accurately and aggressively report and stop giving trump so much misguided and unearned deference - the likes of which tips same paper rarely afforded his opponent.
Anyone who is careless enough to be caught doing 'sex stuff' can't be trusted with the ability to launch a nuclear strike...or even sink a 10-foot putt.

Democrats "have little credibility"?  That's crazy talk.  Democrats consistently beat Republicans in fact checking.  It's only the twisting of those facts by people like you who have made Americans believe that the falsehood that Democrats are credible.  Are you regretting that yet?

Defense contracts increasingly go to make political payoffs to relatively poor Red States where plants provide campaign fodder and claims of prosperity for the future.

Look at Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana. Poor before, poor now. Alabama as a state has many advantages, good government and good public officials are, however, non existent. A huge defense operation on the old Brookley Field site in Mobile pulls in big contracts, but the region is as poor as it ever was.

One sign, the taxes are all skewed to hit the lower income. Near that Mobile site, sales taxes are 10 percent, tax rate for low income is the same as those at the absolute top.

Create housing by filling in the Bay or the water around Manhattan?

It would appear the biggest problem in San Francisco is the commuters from Silicon Valley with real money, who want to living. FWIW, looking around the country, the Bay area and the NYC metropolitan area are doing very well.

They’re being tapped along with other Northeast Corridor taxpayers and other developed states for tax money to keep the Red States solvent. It’s tiresome to see federal money go to Red States that just waste it.

Mr Tillerson represents 500 billion dollar oil drilling rights in Russia that are blocked by American economic sanctions against Russia for the annexation of Crimea and the invasion of the Ukraine. These facts are well known yet the author characterises Mr Tillerson as only 'the friendliest' towards Russia when there is obvious quid pro quo about to be played here. Russia can invade sovereign nations at will ignoring international law because Exxon Mobil needs to provide profits for its shareholders?. Talk about prostituting our value of standing up to dictators and the rule of international law. PEOTUS Trump already says if they are helping us why should there be sanctions? We are about to renew cooperation with a man that leads his nation to annex/ invade territory - killing civilians, bomb civilians in Alleppo, and steals information from American entities worse than Nixon operatives did at watergate - at least Nixon was American. The press needs to stop kid glovin this administration.
Yes, I keep posting this point: it's oil, it's Trump, Exxon and Putin running this three-ring circus.
